question: A stack follows the First In, First Out (FIFO) principle.
The push operation in a stack adds an element at the top.
A stack can be implemented using an array or a linked list.
Stack overflow occurs when trying to pop an element from an empty stack.
Stack underflow happens when the stack is full.
The peek operation removes the top element from the stack.
The top pointer in an empty stack is initialized to -1.
In a stack implemented using an array, the maximum number of elements is fixed.
A stack is considered an Abstract Data Type (ADT) because it is defined by its operations rather than its implementation.
In C, the push function should check if the stack is empty before adding an element.
The pop operation can be performed even when the stack is empty.
A stack is a non-linear data structure.
Stacks are used in function calls and expression evaluation.
The main operations of a stack are push and pop.
A stack allows access to elements in any order.
Stack overflow can be prevented by checking if the stack is full before pushing an element.
In a stack, elements are inserted and deleted from the same end.
A linked list implementation of a stack does not have a fixed size limit.
The LIFO principle of a stack means the first element inserted is the first one removed.
The display operation in a stack prints elements in the order they were inserted.
